Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Novel techniques for the selective collection and separation of highly-oxidized organic compounds through the application of CO2-triggered "switchable" polarity surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1622389
Gentner, Drew

This proposal addresses an important aspect of the chemistry of air pollutants. The research will develop novel tools and methods that overcome present analytical barriers. The principal investigator (PI) will develop new technologies to address future problems related to the environment or other challenges relevant to society. This proposal has clear broad impacts on society and well-being via addressing the environmental health risk of air pollution.

The primary objective of this proposal is to demonstrate the efficacy of "switchable" polarity materials for the collection and/or chromatographic separation of the most elusive components of the atmosphere that have high polarity and hydrophilicity due to their highly oxidized state. The PI will explore and evaluate methods that use switchable surfaces to alter the polarity of sample collection media and/or sample analysis with changes in the stationary phase of gas or liquid chromatography systems. The polarity of switchable materials is increased via reversible reactions with added carbon dioxide (CO2). Subsequent purging with an inert gas or solvent removes the CO2 and returns the material to its low-polarity precursor. This provides a novel and potentially transformative way to selectively collect/separate polar chemical species that are thermally-degraded or lost in other analytical instrumentation. The techniques proposed would seed a new generation of chromatography methods (with Liquid and Gas Chromatography) where the polarity of the stationary phase can be changed rather than the mobile phase, opening new avenues of analysis and potentially reducing solvent needs. There are many applications to gas- and aerosol-phase compounds relevant to the atmosphere, but also to other laboratory methods where polar analytes require collection/separation from a fluid or chromatographic separation without solvents. This includes novel air sampling inlets of minimal size with coupled collection and separation of polar compounds on the same device. There is also the potential for sampling systems that are directly applicable to the study of water-soluble compounds and their aqueous chemistry in the atmosphere. The results of these methods will seed a new understanding of atmospheric oxidation chemistry that will improve models and enable comprehensive air quality management plans. The anticipated results will aid in sustainability science by providing new usable knowledge to model future air quality, formulate policy, and inform the public. The proposal also contributes to training and career development for a postdoctoral scholar. The results will be quickly disseminated to the public via a potential high-impact journal publication and publically available papers and information on the group website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gas- and particle-phase organic compounds play key roles in air quality, including the formation of tropospheric ozone and secondary organic aerosol. Yet, the evolution and fate of highly oxidized compounds as part of complex atmospheric mixtures is uncertain, in part due to limitations in measurement capabilities. The primary objective of this EAGER (Early Concept Grants for Exploratory Research) grant and its interdisciplinary team is to explore the efficacy of novel methods for the collection and analysis of highly polar chemical species. We develop and evaluate methods that use specialized materials in sample collection and/or analysis and couple them to liquid chromatography, gas chromatography, and/or very-high resolution mass spectrometry. This includes multiple prototypes to investigate different materials in a variety of applications, and the production and implementation of novel co-polymers. In all, this work has significant intellectual merit, generates a new area of research, and provides pathways to new approaches to analyze polar gas- or particle-phase chemical species that are often lost in sampling or analytical instrumentation.

Through this grant, we carefully evaluated a range of filter extraction techniques and their efficacy on highly-polar compounds by testing the limits of aerosol filter extract with respect to the range of analytes that we could measure and characterize with LC-ESI analysis. In doing so, we discovered a surprising variability in the chemically-speciated composition of secondary organic aerosol. These results have implications for fundamental and applied chemistry studies, as well as for air quality and climate models (i.e., intellectual merit and broader impacts). One key outcome is the preparation and submission of a manuscript on this discovery (Ditto et al., 2018). An additional manuscript closely connected to the objectives of this proposal is also in preparation. This project’s work has been submitted presented at multiple meetings and workshops.

Other key outcomes related to broader impacts and further intellectual merit include the training and professional development to the postdoctoral scholars, graduate and undergraduate students that worked on the project. It has contributed to the development of novel high-risk science for 2 junior faculty and established new capabilities and foundations to continue to produce novel materials across a flexible range of applications. A variety of polymer formulations were used to create different chemical structures with differing properties and several different phase states (polymers, and gels/ networks). In all, it demonstrates the success of the project in seeding interdisciplinary collaborations to use materials science to solve environmental and analytical chemistry problems. Furthermore, it provided their research groups’ graduate students, undergraduates, and other postdocs with access to a new cutting-edge field of research, that expanded their expertise and generated additional novel ideas and applications.
